Summary of amendments/ Record documents superseded by:

MSE harmonised policy. Supersedes the following documents: Basildon Hospital: CPGU00128 Immunisation policy; Southend Hospital: Immunisation and blood screening standards policy; Broomfield Hospital: Staff immunisation and screening policy.

data.text: Contents
Introduction
The Trust acknowledges its responsibilities to do all that is reasonably practicable to reduce the risks of infection to employees and patients and to comply with health and safety legislation.

The purpose of this policy is to ensure that all employees are adequately screened and appropriately immunised against infectious diseases to reduce the risks of infection transmission to staff and patients in compliance with the legislation.
The Health and Social Care Act (2008) Code of Practice on the prevention and control of infections and related guidance (DH2015) states that registered providers must ensure that:
All staff can access occupational health services or access appropriate occupational health advice;
occupational health policies on the prevention and management of communicable infections in care workers are in place;

decisions on offering immunisation should be made on the basis of a local risk assessment as described in Immunisation against infectious disease (‘The Green Book'). Employers should make vaccines available free of charge to employees if a risk assessment indicates that it is needed (COSHH Regulations 2002);
there is a record of relevant immunisations;

Occupational health services for staff should include risk-based screening for communicable diseases and assessment of immunity to infection after a conditional offer of employment and on-going health surveillance;
offer of relevant immunisations; and

there are arrangements in place for regularly reviewing the immunisation status of care workers and providing vaccinations to staff as necessary in line with Immunisation against infectious disease (‘The Green Book') and other guidance from Public Health England

there are arrangements for identifying and managing healthcare staff infected with hepatitis B or C or HIV and advising about fitness for work and monitoring as necessary, in line with Department of Health guidance;

occupational health services liaise with the UK Advisory Panel for Healthcare Workers Infected with Blood-borne Viruses when advice is needed on procedures that may be carried out by BBV-infected care workers, or when advice on patient tracing, notification and offer of BBV testing may be needed;
a risk assessment is carried out and appropriate referral after accidental occupational exposure to blood and body fluids; and

management of occupational exposure to infection, which may include provision for emergency and out-of-hours treatment, possibly in conjunction with accident and emergency services and on-call infection prevention and control specialists. This should include a specific risk assessment following an exposure prone procedure which is detailed in the Sharps Injury Policy.
Scope
This policy applies to all existing and prospective employees of the Trust including bank, locum, visiting healthcare workers and volunteers. This includes:
Category 1

Staff involved in direct patient care e.g., medical, nursing, midwifery, health care support workers, radiographers, physiotherapists, occupational therapists, plaster technicians, pharmacists, dieticians, speech therapists, audiology and psychology staff. Students who are working directly with patients.
Category 2
Laboratory and pathology, mortuary staff, and ancillary staff who support the laboratories and have access to blood and faecal products (porters, cleaners, admin support if directly support)
Category 3

Non clinical staff in healthcare settings who have social contact with patients but are  not  directly  involved  in  care  e.g.:  receptionists  ward  clerks,  domestics, porters, and maintenance staff.
Definitions

table_items.text: Those procedures where the workers gloved hand may be in contact with sharp instruments, needle tips and sharp tissues (spicules of bone or teeth) inside a patient's body cavity, wound or confined anatomical space where the hands or fingertips may not be completely visible at all times.

This is the term used for staff involved in direct patient care. This includes: Doctors Nurses Midwives Dentists Healthcare assistants Occupational Therapists Physiotherapists Radiographers Plaster technicians Dieticians psychologists audiology staff

Students and volunteers working in these disciplines should be included; for example observers, clinical placement. This group of staff can be subdivided into those who perform exposure prone procedures (EPP) and those who do not (Non-EPP).
Healthcare worker performing EPPs for the first time

This term refers to those HCWs moving into training posts involving EPPs for the first time, for example FY1 or FY2 doctors if screening has not been performed previously. If full screening has been performed in training, for example in medical school and there has been no break in NHS service, screening will only need to be repeated in the absence of documentary evidence.
High prevalence countries for TB are those where the prevalence is greater than 40 cases per 100,000 population. Up to date lists of TB by country can be found in Gov.UK web site.

An IVS is defined according to the following criteria: The employee should show proof of identity with a photograph when the sample is taken. Acceptable ID includes the following: - NHS Trust identity badge - Photo Drivers licence - Passport - National identity card The sample of blood must be taken in the OH department Samples should be delivered to the laboratory in the usual manner, not transported by the employee When results are received from the laboratory, the clinical notes should be checked for a record that the sample was sent by the OH department at the relevant time

This staff group includes: Staff who work with clinical specimens in the laboratory setting, for example: - Haematology - Biochemistry - Microbiology - IPP Staff who work in this area if they are involved in the handling of specimens or clinical waste, for example: - Domestics - Porters - Receptionists - Secretaries - Contractors

This term refers to those staff starting in employment (including returnees to the NHS) who have lived in a country with a high prevalence of tuberculosis for a period of three months or more within the last five years.
Non HCW staff with patient contact
This staff group includes staff who are not involved with clinical care but have regular face to face patient contact , for example: Ward clerks Receptionists in clinical areas
This term refers to those individuals hosted by the Trust to observe clinical work practices. They should not be involved in direct clinical contact with patients but may have social contact.
Occupational Health and Well Being Service

This term relates to a new member of staff starting in employment after a break in service or out of NHS service. This includes returnees who have been working for private or locum agencies in the UK and those who have spent time outside the UK, for example: Voluntary service with medical charities Extended electives Sabbaticals (including tours of duty with the armed services) Periods of unemployment
Staff with no regular patient contact or contact with specimens (Category 3)

This staff group includes staff who work in administrative or support roles who do not have regular face to face contact with patients, for example: Non-clinical managers Secretarial staff Administrative and clerical staff Support staff working in non-clinical areas
Staff working in certain special occupational risk areas (Category 2)

Certain work areas have been identified as posing increased risk of vaccine-preventable occupationally acquired infections. These areas include: Mortuary Incinerator Microbiology laboratories All staff working in these areas in contact with patients/ specimens / clinical waste are included in the level 2 group
This staff group includes staff who can have regular face to face patient contact and/or contact with specimens and/or clinical waste, for example Porters Domestics Ward assistants Housekeeping staff
The administration of antigenic material (a vaccine) to stimulate an individual's immune system to develop adaptive immunity to a pathogen. Vaccines can prevent or reduce morbidity from infection.

Volunteers are individuals engaged through the voluntary services department to help support services in the Trust. This may involve patient contact and in these circumstances should be screened to the same level as non-HCW with patient contact

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees)
4.1.1 Infection Control Committee is responsible for receiving information from and advising on:
Reports of infections and infection control issues including national reports and initiatives that may affect patient or staff health.

effectiveness of the arrangements in place to manage the risks associated with sharps and needle-stick incidents by receiving and monitoring regular reports on the number and type of sharps and needle-stick incidents reported within the Trust
Flu vaccinations and staff uptake
4.1.2 Health andSafety Committee reviews the effectiveness of the arrangements in place to manage the risks associated with vaccine-preventable diseases by
Processing reports received by Occupational Health
Reporting numbers of staff appropriately vaccinated against target to directorate heads
Role and Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust

4.2.1 The  Chief  Executive  has  overall  responsibility  for  ensuring  the  Trust  has management systems in place to enable the effective and safe implementation of this policy, for this policy in particular this extends to establishing and maintaining IPC arrangements across the organisation. This responsibility is delegated to the Director of Infection Prevention and Control.
4.2.2 Executive Director with responsibility for Infection Prevention and Control
The Director of Nursing has delegated responsibility from the Chief Executive for the operation of this policy
Ensures that the Trust Board is advised of the effectiveness of this policy and any shortfalls in meeting the standards set
Chairs the Infection Prevention Committee which will monitor compliance with the effectiveness of the policy
4.2.3 Department Managers are responsible for ensuring:
That all staff are aware of the contents of this policy
That appropriate risk assessments are in place for tasks involving exposure to infectious diseases.
That all staff have received the appropriate health clearance by Occupational Health before commencing work
That temporary staff have been cleared to the same standard which applies to Trust employees
That the HR recruitment team are advised of all posts that will require staff to be cleared for exposure prone procedures
That no healthcare worker is allowed to undertake exposure prone procedures until health clearance has been issued by Occupational Health
That staff are not knowingly exposed to a vaccine preventable disease until they have received the appropriate immunisations
That  they  refer  staff  with  any  signs or  symptoms  of  TB  or  other  potentially infectious disease to Occupational Health
4.2.4 All Employees are responsible for ensuring:
That they provide accurate vaccination history when requested and allow their immunisation data to be held on the Occupational Health database.

That they familiarise themselves with this policy and, where additional screening and vaccinations are required in order to comply with the policy, they should arrange for these to be completed through the Occupational Health

That they are appropriately protected against all communicable diseases whilst at work, this includes the wearing of suitable personal protective equipment (PPE) and adherence to all Infection Prevention and PPE policies.
That they inform their line manager if they have not been vaccinated against or are not immune to any of the vaccine preventable diseases for which they would routinely have been offered vaccination.
That they report any signs or symptoms of TB or other potentially infectious disease to Occupational Health both at pre-employment or during employment.

That they are aware of their duty of care to patients, and any member of staff who may have been exposed to a serious communicable disease, in whatever circumstances, must seek and follow confidential professional advice (e.g. from OH) about whether to undergo testing.
4.2.5 Human Resources Department are responsible for ensuring:

That no staff member commences employment until an appropriate health clearance certificate has been issued by Occupational Health, including confirmation of clearance to undertake Exposure Prone Procedures. Students will have clearance from their own University Occupational Health Departments'.
That all new starters complete a pre-employment questionnaire which is forwarded to Occupational Health for review.
4.2.6 The Occupational Health & Wellbeing Service (OH) is responsible for:

Vaccinating or assessing immunity of Trust staff in line with the recommendations outlined in "The Green Book" where need arises out of work undertaken to fulfil job requirements/duties and to meet the requirements of the Trust to obtain health clearance for staff.
Vaccinating staff where immunisation is required as set out in the vaccination table (Appendix 1).
Undertaking health screening on employment in line with current employment policies
Providing clearance on new employees if fit to commence work, or advice regarding work adjustments following pre-employment assessment
Performing appropriate screening if individuals provide inadequate evidence of immunity / non-infectivity.
Issuing health clearance for EPP roles only when appropriate screening results have been obtained.
Notifying the line manager when staff fail to attend OH appointments
Notifying the line manager when an individual declines vaccination with a report stating that OH clearance cannot be provided.
Maintaining accurate and contemporaneous records of staff vaccinations
Recalling staff for further vaccination / screening when required
Providing confidential advice and support to staff that have had or develop an infectious disease
Providing copies of immunisation /infection screening records for staff on request.
4.2.7 Volunteers.

All pre-employment checks are carried out in accordance with the NHS Employment Check Standards, which are mandatory for all applicants for NHS positions in on- going NHS employment, including volunteers. Those directly recruited by the Trust should be made aware of the Trust immunisation and health screening policy. They will be required to undergo health screening. Immunisation and screening will be undertaken commensurate with their role.

4.2.8 Agency staff / students /honorary contracts / work placements / contractors must comply with the vaccination and screening standards outlined in this policy. Those in the Trust responsible for agency contracts will ensure that the organisations they are contracting with comply with the policy standards.
Health screening process

Staff immunisation and infection screening is an important control measure for preventing the spread of infectious diseases. Immunisation and infection screening is undertaken when staff are appointed to post.

All new employees to the Trust are required to complete an online Pre Placement Questionnaire (PPQ) which is assessed by OH. Staff who change roles are also required to complete a modified PPQ to indicate if there are new health issues to be assessed or additional immunisation requirements. Further information pertaining to health and vaccination history may be required via telephone, email or face to face.
All new starters are requested to provide documentary evidence of prior vaccinations or tests of immunity.

Guidance dictates that if the healthcare worker is to have direct contact with patients or patient specimens, or are to work within a clinical area they will require a standard health check for Tuberculosis (TB), Measles, Rubella and Chickenpox. If their post exposes the healthcare worker to bodily fluids including blood, clinical or infectious waste they will also require immunity to Hepatitis B achieved through a course of Hepatitis B immunisations.
Staff working with pregnant women or infants are a priority group for vaccination against Pertussis.
Hepatitis C and HIV screening are available on request for all staff.

If the healthcare worker is to have direct contact with patients and will also undertake exposure prone procedures they are required to undergo additional health screening which requires the healthcare worker to demonstrate their non- infectivity to Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C and HIV. See Appendix 1, Immunisation and Blood Screening Standards
Health clearance will not be issued in the following circumstances:
Workers recruited to EPP posts with insufficient evidence of Hepatitis B surface antigen, Hepatitis C antibodies and HIV antibodies status.
New staff with symptoms consistent with TB without a recent chest X-ray and medical review.
Food handlers who report infection with typhoid / paratyphoid or contact with infected individuals within the last 21 days without receiving further advice from the Health Protection Agency.
Inclusion in the immunisation programme will be instigated once the employee has commenced work as follows:
Immunisations, where required should be commenced during the induction period.

Failure to attend  appointments will require communication with the line manager as the employee will need to be risk assessed to ensure they are able to safely continue to work within their employed area.
Refusal to receive vaccinations or have serology taken will require a disclaimer and will lead to correspondence with the line manager for risk assessment.
Additional Health Clearance for Exposure Prone Procedures (EPP) Workers
5.10.1 For new HCWs, including students who will perform exposure prone procedures, additional health clearance will also be required. Additional health clearance means being non-infectious for:
HIV (antibody negative)
Hepatitis B (surface antigen negative, or if positive, e-antigen negative with a viral load of 200 IU/ml or less): and
Hepatitis C (anti body negative or, if positive, negative for Hepatitis C RNA)

5.10.2 All EPP workers have a professional duty to stop performing EPP work if they have acquired (or there is a significant risk that they may have acquired) one of these infections. The worker should discuss their concerns with occupational health in confidence.

5.10.3 Certain workers will not be able to undertake work until an appropriate identity validated blood test (IVS) is undertaken by Occupational Health to confirm their non-infectivity to Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C and HIV. These workers include:
Healthcare workers starting their first EPP Nursing, Midwifery or Medical job
Healthcare workers entering training for a career that relies upon the performance of EPPs
Healthcare workers that have been working in a “high risk” area outside the NHS
Healthcare workers who are unable to produce appropriate evidence of previous test results
5.10.4 All such testing is with the employee's informed consent.

5.10.5 In instances where there is insufficient information to clear an applicant or healthcare worker for EPP work the applicant will be asked to attend the Occupational Health Service for screening.
5.10.6 Healthcare workers who apply for a post which requires the performance of EPPs and who decline to be tested for HIV, Hepatitis B and Hepatitis C will not be cleared for EPP work.
Identity Validated Blood Sample (IVS)

5.11.1 It is important that those commissioning laboratory tests for HIV, Hepatitis B and Hepatitis C ensure that samples tested are from the healthcare worker in question. Healthcare workers must not produce their own specimens.

5.11.2 The following standards of good practice for occupational health data recording have been agreed by the Association of National Occupational Health Physicians (ANHOPS) and the Association of NHS Occupational Health Nurses (ANHONS) as the two relevant professional bodies:

Laboratory test results required for clearance for performing EPPs must be derived from an  identity validated sample (IVS). Results should not be recorded in occupational health records if not derived from an IVS.
An IVS is defined according to the following criteria:
5.11.3 All tests for clearance and monitoring must be conducted by an accredited laboratory in the UK. Tests conducted outside of the UK cannot be accepted for these purposes.

5.11.4 Where there are difficulties obtaining a blood sample in the OH department, the employee will be accompanied to phlebotomy by the Occupational Nurse to ensure that the sample is taken and subsequently handed into the laboratory, thus maintaining IVS standards.
Food Handler Screening

5.12.1 All new staff who are appointed to roles which require handling of raw food will be required to complete a supplementary food handler's questionnaire. Further assessment by OH may be required if an infectious disease is identified.
Hepatitis A

Immunisation against Hepatitis A is indicated for those staff who are exposed to raw sewage.   In  practice  this is likely  to  apply  to  staff  working in  Estates  only  or laboratory workers. These staff will be identified by a risk based approach locally to determine who, if any, requires Hepatitis A vaccine.
Hepatitis B
All staff who come into contact with blood in the course of their work should be vaccinated against Hepatitis B. Vaccination is available through OH for all staff groups within this category.

Vaccination involves a primary course of 3 doses of vaccine followed by a blood test to ensure immunity. The anti HB's titre levels should <100 iu/l. A booster after 5 years is then recommended. Further boosters may be recommended following occupational exposures to blood or body fluids.
7.2.1 Response to hepatitis B vaccine

Antibody responses to hepatitis B vaccine vary widely between individuals. It is preferable to achieve anti-HBs levels above 100mIU/ml, although levels of 10mIU/ml or more are generally accepted as enough to protect against infection.

Poor-responders: around 10-15% of adults fail to respond to three doses of vaccine or respond poorly. Poor-responders to vaccine (anti-HBs between 10 and 100mIU/ml) will be offered one additional dose of vaccine at that time. In immunocompetent individuals, further assessment of antibody level is not indicated. A reinforcing booster dose should be given at five years, as for good responders.

Non-responders: An antibody level below 10mIU/ml is classified as a non- response to vaccine, and testing for markers of current or past infection is required (HB core antibody test requested [anti-HBc]; if positive lab will proceed to HBsAg). In non–responders, a repeat course of vaccine is recommended, followed by re-testing of antibodies 1-2 months after the second course. Those who still have anti-HBs levels below 10mIU/ml, and who have no markers of current or past infection, will require Hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) for protection if exposed to the virus e.g. after sharps/needle stick injury from a hepatitis B positive source patient.

Non-responders and EPP: non-responders who perform EPP or undertake clinical duties in renal units or other settings involving renal dialysis require annual testing for HBsAg to ensure they have not become infected with HBV.

Poor/Non responders and Needlestick injuries: After a sharps/ Needlestick injury, poor and non-responders will be assessed as per Needlestick and Sharps Injury Policy. A Hepatitis B booster and Hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) may be required, depending on the nature of the incident and source patient details. The need for HBIG will be determined in conjunction with the Occupational Health Physician. Non-responders to HBV immunisation must have HBsAg checked at 3 and 6 months following a sharps injury.
7.2.2 Hepatitis B Virus Carriers

Hepatitis B acute infection and carriers and EPP: all HCW who are HBsAg positive must cease performing EPP or clinical duties in renal units or other settings involving renal dialysis until their e-antigen status is determined. They must be reviewed by the Occupational Health Physician and referred to a liver specialist.

Hepatitis B virus e-antigen positive: those who are e-antigen positive must refrain from all EPP duties or clinical duties in renal units or other settings involving renal dialysis. E-antigen positive HCW will be given career advice and referred to a physician specialising in liver disease

Hepatitis B virus e-antigen negative: those who are e-antigen negative must be tested for HBV DNA on an annual basis. If the viral DNA load is greater than 200 IU/mL, EPP or clinical duties within renal units or other settings involving renal dialysis must not be performed. Viral load must be tested annually by two Identified Validated Samples (IVS) of 7mls clotted blood taken no less than 4 weeks apart and sent to an accredited laboratory in the UK. Where the viral DNA load does not exceed 200 IU/mL, EPP work and clinical duties in renal units or other settings involving renal dialysis can be resumed for a 12-month period after review by the Occupational Health Physician (unless there is any evidence of transmission to a patient). If a HCW's viral load test has been performed outside the UK, advice should be sought from UKAP.

Treatment Issues. It is for the HCW to decide, in collaboration with their treating physician, whether they wish to take antiviral therapy for occupational health reasons. Breakthrough infection, with increases in serum HBV DNA and in serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) levels can be associated with the emergence of resistant virus. 12 weekly monitoring using sensitive HBV DNA assays should occur and be reviewed by the Occupational Health Physician.

Breakthrough infections.  If this occurs due to the development of resistant strains, the HBV DNA levels rise above 200 IU/mL, the HCW should be restricted from all EPP duties or clinical duties in renal units or other settings involving renal dialysis, until such a time as they have been re-stabilised on different oral antiviral drugs. This would be demonstrated by HBV DNA levels of less than 200 IU/mL on 2 consecutive tests performed no less than 4 weeks apart. .Annual testing then applies as for other e-antigen negative workers.
Hepatitis C
There is currently no vaccination available to protect staff from Hepatitis C (HCV) but there is medical evidence that early treatment of acute infection may prevent chronic carriage of the virus.
All clinical healthcare workers, new to the NHS, will be offered HCV testing on appointment.
All healthcare workers new to the NHS who perform EPPs and those who are new to EPPs will be tested for HCV.
Other healthcare workers who are not new to the NHS or new to EPPs are still required to provide satisfactory evidence of their Hepatitis C status on employment.
Those who are positive should be tested for HCV RNA to detect the presence of current infection. Testing for HCV RNA should be carried out by an accredited specialist virology laboratory.

The Advisory Group on Hepatitis (AGH) has assessed that the risk of transmission of HCV from a HCW of unknown HCV status through EPPs is low and therefore advised that existing HCW's doing EPP's should not be routinely tested for HCV. However, HCV testing should be conducted for existing HCWs who carry out EPPs who are aware they may have been exposed to HCV infection, occupationally (e.g. through a needlestick injury) or otherwise (personally).
HCWs who have antibodies to the HCV and are HCV RNA negative are allowed to continue to perform EPPs.
HCWs who have active, or current infection (i.e. who are HCV RNA positive) should be restricted from performing EPPs.

HCWs living with HCV who have been treated with antiviral therapy and who remain HCV RNA negative for at least 3 months after cessation of treatments can return to performing EPP at that time. A repeat HCV RNA test should be undertaken 3 months later.

Employees who currently undertake EPPs are reminded of their professional obligation to seek advice from the Occupational Health department about testing for Hepatitis C infection if they have been exposed to Hepatitis C in the past.
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)

All clinical healthcare workers new to the NHS will be offered an HIV antibody test on employment. A positive test or declining a test will not affect the employment or training of healthcare workers who are not performing EPPs. However the Occupational Health department will advise on the individual's suitability for particular posts especially if duties may involve exposure to known or undiagnosed Tuberculosis.
HIV screening is mandatory for
All EPP workers new to the NHS or returnees to the NHS in EPP dependant specialities from August
All EPP workers who believe they may have been exposed to HIV where there is a risk of transmission e.g. HIV positive sharps or needlestick injury.
Screening consists of an HIV antibody blood test (Anti HIV) taken under IVS conditions

Practising healthcare workers who undertake EPPs are under a professional duty to seek medical advice on the need to be tested as soon as they are aware they may have been exposed to the HIV infection, occupationally or otherwise and if found to be positive, to obtain and follow appropriate clinical and occupational health advice.
Being HIV positive, or declining a test for HIV, will not affect the employment of healthcare workers who will not be undertaking EPPs.
HIV infected HCWs must meet the following criteria before they can perform EPPs: Either
Be on effective combination antiretroviral therapy (cART), and
Have a plasma viral load<200 copies/mL
Or

Be an elite controller (an elite controller is defined as a person living with HIV who is not receiving antiretroviral therapy and who has maintained their viral load below the limits of assay detection for at least 12 months, based on at least three separate viral load measures)
Be subject to plasma viral load monitoring every  weeks, and
Be under joint supervision of a consultant occupational physician and their training physician, and
Be registered with UKAP Occupational Health Monitoring Register (UKAP- OHR).
At this point, a decision should be made as to whether health clearance could be given for the HCW to commence or resume EPP activities.

HCWs living with HIV who are cleared to perform EPPs are subject to viral load testing every 12 weeks while continuing to perform such procedures. The 12 week period will be taken from the date the previous IVS was drawn.

If a HCW's plasma viral load rises above 1,000 copies/mL, they should be restricted immediately form performing EPPs until after their viral load returns to being consistently below 200 copies/mL in at leastconsecutive tests no less than 12 weeks apart. The significance of any increase in plasma load above 200 copies/mL and below 1,000 copies/mL should be assessed jointly by the Occupational Health Physician and treating physician with input from appropriate local experts (e.g. consultant virologist or microbiologist).
Refer to the Policy for the health clearance and management of health care workers infected with blood borne viruses (Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C and HIV) for further information.
Measles
Measles vaccine is encompassed in the Measles, Mumps & Rubella (MMR) vaccine. Two doses of vaccine administered one month apart are considered sufficient to assume immunity.
All healthcare workers and non-healthcare staff in regular patient contact should provide evidence of immunity to measles. Sufficient evidence would be either:
History of vaccination against measles with 2 doses of MMR vaccine or
Evidence of immunity by blood test Measles IgG positive
Routine serological testing post vaccination is not required.
If insufficient evidence of immunity is provided on commencement the individual will be required to attend the occupational health department for vaccination.
Mumps

Mumps vaccine is encompassed in the MMR vaccine and two doses of vaccine are considered sufficient to assume immunity. There is no requirement for routine screening for any staff groups for mumps infection. Many staff will have been vaccinated through the MMR vaccine.
Rubella
Rubella vaccine is a single vaccination encompassed in the MMR vaccine. Prior to MMR it was administered as a single vaccine.
All healthcare workers, non-healthcare workers and support staff with regular patient contact should provide evidence of immunity to rubella. Sufficient evidence would be either:
Evidence of vaccination against rubella with a single dose of vaccine or
Evidence of immunity by blood test Rubella IgG
Evidence of two doses of MMR vaccine
If insufficient evidence of immunity is provided at initial assessment, the individual will be required to attend the occupational health department for vaccination.
Chicken pox (varicella zoster virus – VZV)

The requirement to immunise all non-immune healthcare workers was introduced in 2003 and all healthcare workers, non-healthcare workers and support staff with regular patient contact will be screened for chickenpox .and are required to provide evidence of immunity. Sufficient evidence would include:
History of chickenpox / shingles infection if childhood spent in temperate region
Evidence of immunity by blood test VZV IgG (immunisation should be given if result is negative or equivocal).
History of vaccination against VZV – Two doses of vaccine one month apart

As Chickenpox is a common childhood illness in the UK a history of past infection is considered to be adequate evidence of immunity. Healthcare workers who do not have a clear history of previous infection or who were raised abroad will be tested for varicella antibodies and vaccinated if found to be susceptible.
Tuberculosis (TB)

Employees new to the NHS who will be working with patients or clinical specimens should not start work until they have completed a TB screen or health check, or documentary evidence is provided of such screening having taken place within the preceding 12 months. Pre-placement health screening is completed via the on line health questionnaire.
All healthcare workers will be screened as follows:
Symptoms and signs enquiry via pre-employment health questionnaire (PPQ)
Assessment of personal or family history of tuberculosis (via PPQ)
Documented evidence of TB skin (or interferon-gamma release assay) testing within the past 5 years and / or
The presence or absence of a BCG scar as evidenced by an occupational health practitioner
A history of living/working overseas to assess if new entrant (UK)
If the healthcare worker has no evidence of a BCG scar, previous Mantoux or IGRA test, then an appointment will be offered for a Mantoux test and if negative, a BCG vaccination will be arranged.
If the Mantoux test is positive, a T-spot (interferon-gamma release assay) test should be undertaken and if this is positive, assessment for active and latent TB should be made (see 15).
If a Mantoux test is unavailable, a T-spot (interferon-gamma release assay) test should be offered to new NHS employees who are from a high incidence country.

Employees who will be working with patients or clinical specimens and who are Mantoux or interferon-gamma release assay negative should have an individual risk assessment for HIV infection before the BCG vaccine is given.
The BCG vaccination will be offered to all healthcare workers of any age who:
New to the NHS
From countries of high TB incidence or who have had contact with patients in settings with a high TB prevalence
Are previously unvaccinated (that is without adequate documentation or a characteristic scar), and
Will have contact with patients and/or clinical materials
T Spot test is negative
Mantoux test within last 3 months which is less than 5mm.
Have no evidence of HIV infection or other contraindications.

The Green Book (2018) states that BCG efficacy data in adults over the age of 35 years is scarce. Nevertheless, because these groups have a high exposure risk, and given the absence of safety concerns, it is likely that benefits outweigh risks for vaccinating individuals over the age of 35 years with BCG.
If a member of staff declines a BCG vaccine when it is recommended the risks should be explained and the manager informed. Work restrictions may be necessary following a risk assessment.
Referral for medical assessment for TB

All staff that have symptoms suggestive of TB, either identified through the PPQ or via contact with OH for existing staff, should have further assessment. A T -Spot or IGRA test should be completed. A chest X ray, if not recently performed may be indicated. Managers will not be routinely advised of attendance unless fitness for work issues or work restrictions are necessary.

If the chest X ray is normal and there are no symptoms consistent with TB present, the staff member may continue to attend work. Referral to the Chest clinic will be made for positive IGRA or T-Spot tests or positive Mantoux test (>5mm).
Surveillance – during employment

Staff who have visited or intend to visit a country where there is a high incidence of tuberculosis (see WHO – Country data for world TB), and stay for longer than 6 weeks should contact occupational health if they are working in a high risk area which include:
Antenatal or maternity
Infectious diseases areas
Oncology / Immunosuppression wards
Paediatrics
General medical and respiratory medicine departments

If there is a TB incident within a clinical area, OH should be advised of the staff in contact with the patient and reissue information on symptoms. This should be coordinated by the manager responsible for the work area where the incident occurred.
Poliomyelitis, tetanus and diphtheria

Polio, tetanus and diphtheria combined vaccine is part of the UK national vaccination campaign. Usually five doses of polio containing vaccine administered at appropriate intervals are considered to give satisfactory long term protection. If the national vaccination schedule is strictly followed, the course is usually complete by the age of 15 years.

If a course is interrupted and incomplete, it is recommended it is resumed and not repeated. The previous oral vaccine has now been replaced by an injectable form of vaccine (included in Td/IPV) which can be used to continue the course. This can be provided in the community by the General Practitioner.

Staff working in areas where they regularly handle faecal waste or specimens are more likely to be exposed to polio virus, and evidence of a booster vaccination every ten years is required in the following staff groups:
microbiology staff
mortuary staff
Pertussis (Whooping Cough)

Priority 1: Healthcare workers who have not received a pertussis-containing vaccine in the last 5 years and have regular contact with pregnant women or young infants (those under 3 months old). This includes:
clinical staff working with women in the last month of pregnancy (for example midwifery, obstetrics and maternity settings)
neonatal and paediatric intensive care staff who are likely to have close and or prolonged clinical contact with severely ill young infants
Priority 2: HCWs with regular clinical contact with young unimmunised infants in hospital or community settings. This includes:
general paediatric staff
paediatric cardiology staff
paediatric surgery staff
health visitor staff
Influenza

The Department of Health recommends annual immunisation against seasonal influenza for healthcare workers because it has been shown, in some healthcare settings, to reduce morbidity and mortality of patients.

OH offers annual influenza immunisations to all Trust staff, actively encouraging uptake amongst frontline healthcare workers. OH will liaise with the Trust to optimise uptake and facilitate assess to vaccination, working with the Communications and operational teams to publicise the campaign.
All Trust staff are offered the vaccine free of charge, but HCW's and staff in direct patient contact are given priority in the event of shortage of supply.
Anonymised uptake figures are provided to the Trust during the vaccination campaign.
Typhoid

Typhoid fever is rare in the UK as sanitation standards are high. Usually cases are imported and are associated with foreign travel. Typhoid immunisation is not indicated as an occupational immunisation for HCW's unless laboratory staff are identified as handlers of S typhi in the course of their work. These staff will be identified by a risk based approach locally to determine who requires the typhoid vaccine.
Infected health care workers
Blood-borne virus infections.

21.1.1 If a staff member is identified as having hepatitis B, hepatitis C or HIV whilst in employment, an assessment of the individuals work activity will be required. If the individual has worked in a role that may involve EPP, the Occupational Health Physician should notify the Medical Director and Director of Public Health who will review the situation and decide if a patient notification exercise is required. Also consulted may be:
Consultant for Incommunicable Disease control;
Regional epidemiologists;
Regional Directors of Public Health;
UKAP.
21.1.2 Hepatitis B and hepatitis C are notifiable diseases and the OHP should ensure that the local health protection agency is informed of the diagnosis.
Other infections.

21.2.1  If a staff member believes him/herself to be infected with an active infectious disease such as chicken pox, measles or TB the individual should restrict themselves from work and advise OH and infection control for further advice. If an infectious disease is confirmed further contact tracing may be required.
Management of blood exposure incidents and post exposure
prophylaxis
Management of blood exposure incidents is covered in the Policy for the Management of Needlestick, Sharps and Splash Injuries. Key points of note are:

Hepatitis B - Specific Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin (HBIG) is available for passive protection against Hepatitis B exposure, whenever immediate protection is required. One dose of HBIG is sufficient (usually 500 iu for adults). This should be combined with the simultaneous administration of Hepatitis B vaccine. It is recommended that the HBIG and Hepatitis B vaccine is commenced no later than 24 hours following exposure and no later than  hours.

HIV - Post exposure prophylaxis (PEP) should be commenced if the member of staff sustains a needle stick, sharp or splash injury from a high risk source. It is important that a risk assessment is completed and treatment commenced as soon as possible post incident. Three days' supply of PEP is held in ED and the staff member will be advised to attend the Sexual Health Clinic for follow up.

Hepatitis C - Currently there is no effective post-exposure prophylaxis against hepatitis C infection. Current evidence suggests that if an individual sero- converts following an exposure incident, then prompt treatment with anti-viral agents are likely to clear the virus. OH will arrange for an early referral to specialists in liver disease.
Confidentiality
Occupational  Health  records  are  held  electronically  and  are  separate  from  the hospital notes. OH notes and information are not released without consent from the individual concerned.

If a HCW is identified as infected, consent is sought to disclose information where there is a risk to patients or public health. Information on infected HWC will only be disclosed without consent in exceptional circumstances (where justification is made) where it is considered necessary for the purposes of the prevention of the spread of infection.

Maintaining the confidence of a BBV infected HCW in this respect is very important, but it is also important that the HCW is counselled at an early stage about their own responsibilities if a patient notification exercise is possible. It is important that HCW's do not share the information with anyone other than those who really need to know. In particular, HCW's should not discuss the problem with colleagues at work. A HCW may wish to inform their manager in confidence (if not already aware) although this is not mandatory.

In routine screening managers are informed of work restrictions only where relevant to the job. For example, if a hepatitis C infected HCW works in a non-EPP role, no additional restrictions are put in place.
Breach of confidentiality is serious and will be considered in accordance with the Trust's disciplinary policy.
Reporting infections under RIDDOR
An infection that is considered occupationally acquired should be reported to the HSE under the Reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations (RIDDOR) (1995)
Vaccination records and recalls for vaccination

Under the COSHH Regulations (regulation 11), a health record should be maintained with the dates and record of the immunisation status. This should address the individual's fitness for work or if additional restrictions are required. This should be accessible by the individual's manager to ensure appropriate control measures are in place to protect the individual at work.
This record should:
Include personal details of the individual;
Include dates and records of immunisation / protection status and when further action is required;
Address the individuals fitness for work or any special precautions that should be taken to protect the individual against occupationally acquired infections.

A health record should not include confidential clinical information but should contain an Occupational Health assessment of immune status and if a further risk assessment is required. It is not the same as a clinical record as it needs to be accessible by the employer. For example, a manager needs to know whether someone is immune or not, but not necessarily the level of immunity or any reasons for lack of immunity which would be recorded within the clinical records.

The Occupational Health & Wellbeing service maintains a clinical record on each staff member of the Trust that includes each employees screening and vaccination results. Recalls are generated from this to remind staff for vaccination. Managers are responsible for ensuring their staff members attend for vaccination when recalls are generated.
Electronic storage of immunisation records (cohort)

The Cohort Occupational Health database has the facility to record immunisation and infection screening data and vaccination recalls. Reports can be provided to managers on their staff immune status and recalls for vaccination are sent by Occupational Health. Individuals can be provided with a copy of their records and this should be requested in email.
The process should outline any exceptions, for example ‘this policy does not cover situations such as XXXXX. Such situations are covered by policy XXXXX'. - Just type over this text.
Training requirements
This policy is in immediate effect from its agreement date. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via OH.
Staff administering vaccinations will be required to update annually as per PHE guidelines.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined  below  is  the  Trust's  process  of  monitoring  compliance  with,  and  the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Senior Leadership Teams HR meetings Infection Control Committee
Infection control committee Health and Safety Committee

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Infection Prevention and Control Committee which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the key staff and services areas (as outlined in appendix 1) of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 2)
